Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Thought those clouds this morning spelled rain for sure, but it's turned into a beautiful day, wouldn't you say, Sergeant Burrows?

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: I warned you about that cheerful shit.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Friend here did a half-gainer with a firebird tuck from the third floor.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Not unless he decided not to bother opening the window first.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Well, he wasn't exactly in a condition to walk a chalk line when we got here. You're welcome to try and smell his breath if you like, that is if you can find the mouth.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: On their way. Willie promises a white paper tomorrow. Or Wednesday, depending on his golf game.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Mr. Jiminez. Was taking a short cut to his job at a packing plant on San Pedro. First thing he remembers about the deceased is several vital organs bouncing off his windshield.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Have you had him walk a chalk line?

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: No wallet, license, nothing. He is missing one or two things, though.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: We've found everything else -- and what fun that was, let me tell you -- but the eyes are still AWOL. Might just be stuck in the radiator grill. Little weird though.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Both popping out together like that. Worth a page in my scrapbook.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: There are, what an intelligent, experienced detective like yourself could possibly construe as signs of a struggle.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Naturally nobody saw or heard anything.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: In such a fine establishment as this?

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Ku San's on fourteenth is still open for another hour. Whatd'ya say we pull out the 'ol "SUICIDE" rubber stamp and get some lunch. Rancid chow mein and watered beer for under three bucks.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: That usually happens when you break a window.

Speaker: burrows
Dialogue: Arizona desert, I think. Which is exactly where I'm going to be in two years, three months.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Hey bright eyes, what's the deal being out here all alone without a coat?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Pig out on all the cake?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Oh, there might be one, tiny, skinny piece left, but you're gonna have to race me for it.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I was just looking for my "SUICIDE" rubber stamp.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I'm okay.  Must have rained over the golf course this morning. I'll be right over.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Hey, Willie, sorry to hear about the weather.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Where would you like me to start?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I think we can skip the cause of death.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: All right. To begin with, your man has no eyes.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Weren't stuck in the radiator grill?

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: No, he never had any eyes. We checked the sockets. There's no optic nerve, muscle pores, loose viscus, nothing.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: We also did a toxicology on his blood: High sodium, elevated selenium, no floating cholesterol platelets, trace ammonia.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: No, it's actually pretty common -- for an aborted fetus.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I should have listened to Burrows...

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: We also did a bone section. Wasn't that much trouble since most of them were sticking out of his chest anyway.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: When babies grow up their bones get larger by adding calcium layers over the interior haversham canals. Child growth isn't uniform though, comes in spurts that always leave growth rings in the bone. Everybody has them -- except your man. That would, to a hasty observer, seem to indicate he had never been a child.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I assume you, a cautious and learned observer, of course have an explanation.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Not even remotely. Want to hear the last one?

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: He's a hermaphrodite.  -- Has both male and female sex organs.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Yeah, you can be impotent and frigid all at the same time -- they don't normally work.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Well, I'd love to say thank you, but --

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Oh, I also have a bonus prize for you.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Found this sealed in his coat lining.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: A pretty old one, I think.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: We checked it out inside. Thought there might be a name or fingerprint somewhere. All we found was a curled page marking the fourteenth chapter of St. John's Revelations.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: There is no fourteenth chapter to Revelations.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Maybe this is the teacher's edition.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Can you sit on all this a few days, Willie? Not circulate the file? I need some time before all the questions start.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: Oooh, are we breaking the rules again?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: In a minute, in a minute...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You could save my life with some coffee.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You don't want to hear about it.  Or maybe you do.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Shouldn't they be getting to school?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Impromptu field trip. I'm broadening their minds. And sparing them the sight of their beloved chauffeur barfing his guts out.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I hate horses. How was the canyon? Honey-suckle out yet?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: I hate that canyon. I hate this this whole plateau. Too many goddamn ghosts. Leave it to them I say. San Diego, that's where I'm going. Or Oxnard. I like the sound of that. Ox- nard.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Oh lord protect us, another romantic pale face in love with the desert.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Just got to give it a chance.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Try growing up here.  Speaking of romantic pale faces, the rumor mill is in high gear again.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: That funny looking guy from Window Rock. The BIA lawyer.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You're a credit to the community.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: All right children, looks sharp! This is a school day! And no talking loud!

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: This is "Camposaurus". Camposaurus was a herbavore, which meant he only ate plants. Camposaur stayed mostly to himself and never bothered anyone.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: This is a leg fragment that belongs to the killer of the plateau, Alosaurus. Alosaurus was a vicious carnivore, which meant he'd eat anything that moved, especially nice, juicy Camposaurs.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Both these guys lived together right here on the White Rock plateau eighty million years ago, when this area used to be on the banks of a huge, shallow sea. Remember how we talked about how sedimentation fossilizes bones? That's also what made the hills out behind our town and put the copper in the ground.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Just a tiny bit, Alex. Do you know why? Uranium, that's the rock they use in nuclear power plants --

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: And bombs Alex, yes, is all through these hills naturally. Millions of years ago the dinosaurs here ate plants and drank water which had uranium in it that became concentrated in their bones, which is exactly how, with Mr. Geiger counter here, we're going to find some.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: -- Hey. Come on. What's the deal, Brian?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: All right, Brian. You get one free insult. Make it good.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I got one! I got one!

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I'm all done with the cleaning, Miss Henley.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Thank you, Jason. I appreciate it.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Find out what it is, yet?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Well, it's either a 44 million year old Strychtosaurus or that cow Mr. Sorenson lost last winter.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Sure, Miss Henley. Thanks. See ya.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You don't look so good, Simon.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Does Miss Henley know you're here?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: No one does, Mary. Can we keep it just our secret. For a little while?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: It was nice meeting you, Mary.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Are you hungry? I could bring something.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Gee Jerry, you look like shit.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Hmmm. Still a little life left in you. Barely.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: There's something I want you to do for me.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I just want to... Why won't you let me...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You need some new clothes, son.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Aw come on, don't start. You know how I hate that...

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I'm so tired. I'm so goddamn tired.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Watch the profanity. -- Just one more favor. Honest.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I want you to get something for me. A few personal effects the cops ripped off from the lovely Allenwood Arms on Seventh Street. It'll be sitting in their property room down on San Julian.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: I'm supposed to just go in there? Like this?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Give you a bath, put on some decent clothes,  Maybe a very large brim hat, you'll be fine. Just go in between five and five-ten, it's a shift change and nobody'll notice you.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: This should be more or less up to date.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Got a name this stuff is under?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'll see you tonight.  Here's some bus fare.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Can I ask you about something?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: It has to stay between us. I need your word on it.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: As a racquetball player or a priest?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I'll take the priest for the moment.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: It's a case. We found this guy. He was... different. But he had on him an old bible.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: More than a little. They're the best. Sixth century. Hand illuminated. Vichini only did twenty, each pocket size for a king to carry into battle beside his heart. Some consider them the finest bibles ever made. I thought they'd all be in museums. What are you doing with it?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: It's has a bonus chapter to St, John's Revelations.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: "And as in the first war, the angels so fought over the nature of their God, and there was much vanity and destruction in heaven. For some angels called their Lord the son of God, and others called Him the begotten father of Jesus Christ." What do you think?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I've never heard that quote before. Theologically, The "first war" obviously refers to the war in heaven where Michael the archangel threw out Satan and his gang. Old time bible stuff. But this implies there was a second war. That's news to me.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, it's a fairly common theological debate. Or was. The idea that if Christ is God's son, does that make him less than God or are they the same being in different forms. That very argument almost tore the early Christian church apart in the 4th Century. That was the good old days when people actually worried about theology. Anyway, it was settled when the bishops of the world got to together at the Council of Nicene in 325 and hashed out the various interpretations of scripture into a uniform dogma of belief. The result was the Nicene Creed, which basically said that Christ was in fact the same as God and was owed the same power and respect as the Father. That they were the same.  But it's not exactly the sort of thing angels would fight over.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, they could just ask God, right?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Do you think it's possible that John might have written that extra chapter?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Who knows? Vichini was the greatest biblical scholar of the age, some claimed he made his own translations from the original writings. Maybe he did find some unknown writings by John. It's possible I suppose. John always was a little negative about angels. All this actually has something to do with an LAPD murder?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I don't know yet. Maybe. Probably not.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I hate to break it you, but that particular family spat has been settled for 1,600 years. Nobody loses sleep over it anymore. Honest.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: What did John have against angels?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, he didn't trust them much. All that running around smiting and killing in the name of the Lord. God's wild bunch. He thought it made them fickle and vain. One click above ghosts. Satan didn't help the image much either.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Well, he did start as an angel.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: So when are you going to get a real job?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You almost did it once. I never saw a seminary student more called to the collar than you. Why didn't you ever become ordained?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: You'll have to tell it to me sometime.

Speaker: brian
Dialogue: I think she's out back somewhere.

Speaker: allison
Dialogue: We haven't seen her since lunch.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: We're you guys up in the...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Okay everybody, get started on today's reading. Quietly. I'll be right back.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: It's not her I'm worried about.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Small job. Mostly done now. Just passing through.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: This is school property, you can't sleep here.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: It wasn't part of the plan. Honest.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I'll have to call the police.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I wish you wouldn't, but I understand.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I'm sure you are.  You were nice to give me the food.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I haven't much time, Mary. And since you've been so nice to me, there's something I'd very much like to give to you.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Just for a little while. Something very special. Can you keep it a secret? The biggest secret ever?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: What's the matter, pumpkin? Did you eat something?  Did he give you something?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I'll have the school send over a doctor.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: ...He's was just laying up there. I thought, with the kids and everything...

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Most of my boys are up the highway on a tanker spill at the moment. They may be a while. These people are rarely any problem. I'll have a deputy come by tonight or tomorrow and shoo him out.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: They all do, ma'am. Inside or out, they're all damaged goods.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Why is my friendly coroner, after a long day at work, calling me at home?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I have something you'll want to see.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: No, you'll definitely want to see this.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: They also took the autopsy file.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: He, she, it. They took it. They also lifted all the physical evidence from the San Julian impound.

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: The cop at the desk is in the hospital as we speak with a broken collarbone. Everyone else was down the hall watching the basketball playoffs.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Looks like the snow angels we used to make as kids. Lie down in a clean bank. Move your arms up and down...

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: You know what this means. Our friend's cleaned out all the evidence on this guy. Everything.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Did the cop get a look at who nailed him?

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: You gonna figure this one out, Tom?

Speaker: coroner
Dialogue: When you do, give me a call. Tell me I'm not crazy.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: -- Soon. Honest. Don't be a pest about it.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Oh, maybe five or six times a week.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I need to go to Arizona.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: So I can give you a straight answer.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Why do you need me? I can hardly walk now.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Some things are human work, son. Live or dead, human work. Besides, I like you.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I can always smell a graveyard.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I always enjoy watching you work, Jerry.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: How did I ever get you in my life?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Come on, you didn't really want to kill yourself.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: But I did it, didn't I? I did kill myself.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: And you're just keeping me alive.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Thank you, Jerry. I'm touched. Really.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Ah, but it's not what's on the outside that matters --

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Oooh, bad news for the war effort.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Now, if you were a soul, where would you hide?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: The world's the usual. Except for a guppy. the world's minus one guppy this morning.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: They keep asking for Uncle Tommy. The only man that can make stuffed bears talk.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: My one true calling. What's up?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I just thought I should call.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: It's my job, Jan. I go places sometimes.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I just had this terrible feeling about it. What's happening, Tom?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I miss you. Even when you're here. I miss you. I miss my brother. It's been four years, Tom, since...

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: We're the only blood family we have left, you and me. I worry about you.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Sorry about the dawn-attack call. I love you.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Why can't this shit ever go down in Miami? Or Bora Bora? I feel like I've spent my whole damn stay in gin swills like this.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Don't mind me. Just along for the ride.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: So, what shall we talk about? Theology?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I'm a little talked out on theology.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Don't happen to have it on you by chance?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That would have been too easy.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Now. Where's the soul?  You know. So high. Used to reside in the recently departed General Hawthorne.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Have it your way, big guy.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: Do you even remember what this war's about?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: That's hardly the point, is it?

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I guess I never did get the point.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: How do you do it, Gabriel? How do you go on and on in this place?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I like it here, Simon. I always have.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Then join us, Simon. Reject the Nicene Council. We were here first.

Speaker: simon
Dialogue: I can't do it, Gabriel. I don't even know why anymore, but I can't.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I can do this for five months, Simon...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Where is it? Where did you put it?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'm just about out of tricks here. You're a tough one, friend. Old school.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: You may want to skip this, ma'am.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Were any of your students up here?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: He found nothing. But something is in her. I know. Something the Belagaana doctor can't see. The night people have been around two days now. It is a warning.  So we have called the hand trembler. To find if she must have an Enemy Ghost Way.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: And to what do I owe the thrill of a visit from a So Cal homicide cop?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Run of of the mill psycho killer body dismemberment on our end. The usual.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Got a lead I wanted to run down Chimney Rock way. Thought I'd do the courtesy of telling you first.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: You're welcome to put a babysitter on me if you like.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Son, this is the third biggest county in the country, not even counting the 25,000 square mile Indian reservation right next door, and I've got fewer men than just one of your little palm tree precincts to cover all of it. 'Fraid the only help you're gonna get from me, short of another shoot out at the OK Corral, is that cup of coffee in your hand. A middle-aged secretary enters with a stack of paper.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Here's the last week's watch reports.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Bobby just called this in from Chimney Rock.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Sent a car up there this morning. Teacher complained some vagrant was sleeping in her schoolhouse.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Damn it, get Bobby on the phone, Clarice. What the hell is this suppose to be?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Small piece of advice, Lt. Dagget, that I give free of charge to all visiting big city policemen: It's wild country up there. Always has been, always will be. You come across anything that snarls, you call me first, hear?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I never turn down advice, Sheriff. Especially when it's free.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: How long ago was he buried?

Speaker: grave keeper
Dialogue: Somebody dug him up last night. I just finished putting him back.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Can I help you with something?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Tom Dagget. I'm with the police.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I'd like to ask you a few questions.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I've kinda got my hands full right now.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Okay, everbody stays on the courts today.  -- I mean it.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Nearly all ghosts now. When the copper mine closed it took most of the town with it. We just teach out of this one corner of the schoolhouse now. Rest of it's been abandoned for years.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Do it again and I'll put your head in the door and slam it.  Love and understanding are important tools in education.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: The man upstairs, did you talk to him?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I wanted to know what the hell he was doing there.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: That it wasn't part of the plan. He looked hurt. Bloody. Like someone had cut him. That happens here.  Was that... stuff... on the floor really him?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Did any of the children talk to him?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: She's home sick from school today.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Can I speak with her parents?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: They're dead. She lives with her grandmother. I'll have to ask her.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: All right.  This is my number at the hotel.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: The General? Saw him here and there. It's a small town.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: About a million years ago. His interests lately were more like gardening and herbal tea.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Did you go to the funeral?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: There are no secrets in small towns, Mr. Dagget, dark or otherwise.

Speaker: gabriel's voice
Dialogue: It's unusual to see someone of your age in church on a weekday.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Don't get me wrong. I think it's an excellent sign of character.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Never mind him. He shouldn't even be in here. Least not standing.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I will. Have you found what you're looking for?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You'll let me know? When you find it?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Have a seat. You need a card. Here, play one of mine.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You must learn to shed your high- strung ways, pale face. You must learn the spirit joy in patience, peace, and making fifty or sixty bucks.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: John, this is Mr. Dagget. Says he's with the police, though judging by his coat and basic command of the english language, I don't think it's from anywhere around here.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Long way from home, Tom-from-Los- Angeles.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: -- Hey, wait. I won. I won!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I'm not very good at this...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: So how's our star pupil feeling today?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Mary? The school doctor came by. Declared it "Non-specific gastrointestinal disorder".

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Latin for "I don't have the slightest fucking idea".

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Will she be able to talk with me?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: That's up to her.  Mary's grandmother called a hand trembler.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Depends what the hand trembler says. People call them in when they think a witch or a Yei is trying to sprinkle corpse sickness in their hogan, or if the Night People have been hanging around too much. Night people screw around a lot, but they're good at warning of evil ghosts.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Too much fucking sky in the desert. It pushes on you.  Sometimes I wonder if anyone in heaven even knows this place is here...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Where do you keep the coffee in this joint?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: What happens if the hand trembler says a ghost has been...

Speaker: john
Dialogue: -- Messing with Mary? If you're smart you say thank you very much and forget about it. But if you're heavy traditional, and Mary's people are serious traditional, you have an Enemy Ghost Way.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Goddamn expensive. It's a Sing to purify and drive off the corpse sickness. Two days of dancing and ceremony and feeding the whole damn village. Not even to mention hiring the yataallii, if you can even find one these days. And you can bet they don't come cheap. But every clan does it a bit different. Especially Mary's.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: The Bitter Sky Clan. Hard core reservation. No lights, no running water, no HBO. Their village is out on the edge of Old Woman Butte. Million miles from anything. Witch country. Settled right there in the Dead People Land where no one else would, right on top of the old Anasazi village. They're a dying clan. Just the old ones now. All alone out there in the middle of nothing.  They can keep it.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Do people really still believe in it all? Ghosts, Sings, corpse sickness?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Depends, I guess. Sometimes you go along because it's a village thing, or you don't want to disappoint grandma. But sometimes, when you're alone out there, far from town, and the wind kicks up and sneaks into your hogan... I don't know.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I think John's out for the evening.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: So how does a person like you end up teaching here?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: When I was younger I used to believe that no matter how much you mucked around in your life, one day, if you listened hard enough, a voice would tell you what you were really cut out to do. And when it didn't show up on schedule I decided to go look for it. And I looked in a lot of places, believe me. I drove that road out there so far that the end became the beginning again. And it was when I got here that I realized there never was going to be a voice. So I stopped looking and took the first job they offered me. That make any sense to you?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Oh, I know all about voices. Problem is not all of them are very nice.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: How did you end up a cop?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: It was the evil of two lessers.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: No. When you get to know me I can be down right evasive.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Thanks for the lift. Tomorrow at noon? At the little girl's house?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: First trailer on the highway past town.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I must say, Mr. Dagget, that you don't seem very like a police officer to me.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: That's what my bosses keep saying.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I meant it as a compliment.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: ...There, and there. Now pucker your lips... aim it that way, and just blow a little bit, this is a special trumpet.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Very good, Timmy. Very good. Here, have a Junior Mint on me. Open up.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: And did you see the man upstairs, Sandra?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: And who did, Sandra. Who talked to the man?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You've got very pretty teeth, Sandra. Here, let me see...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: What the hell do you think you're doing?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Just talking to the kids, Ma'am.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Get off his knee, Sandra. Everyone else, go inside. Now.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: See ya, kids. Be sure to study your math.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I don't know what the hell is going on, but you both better get out of here. Right now.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: ...You have no idea what's going on.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Al! Keep an eye on the children for me. I'll be right back. And call the sheriff.

Speaker: janitor
Dialogue: Sheriff? What the hell do I tell him?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: You weren't suppose to be here till noon.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I wanted to check on her.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: This is Mr. Dagget, Mary. He'd like to ask you some questions. You don't have to answer if you don't want to.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Mary, when you talked to man up in the building --

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Yes, Simon. What did Simon say?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm good at it. I'm very clever.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: We'll have to play together sometime.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Simon even said so. He also asked if I could keep a secret.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Then it wouldn't be a secret.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: You're a good friend not to tell, Mary. But I'm a friend of Simon's too. So if you ever want to tell, you can to me. Okay?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Have you ever killed a chinaman?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: They don't bleed. Not the way you and I do. Or maybe it was just the cold...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I've killed them, you know. Lots. You could always tell when they were coming. There'd be the trumpets first. Every note flat. Then those songs... After that they'd charge. Right down through the snow. The guns would freeze and it would be just knives... It was so cold and there were so many of them. But I was smarter than they were. Even at Chosin, I was smarter...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It scares me, Miss Henley. I hate it. Please, make it stop!

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to --

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: It's all right, Miss Henley. We know you love Mary...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: What are we going to do?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: She's going to have the Enemy Ghost Way. We leave this afternoon.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Where will they do the ceremony?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: In the home village. The Hand Trembler must have found corpse sickness...

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: They're taking her away? Shouldn't she see a doctor?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: She's already seen a doctor.  That son of a bitch...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Gabriel the children called him. The little shit was hanging around my kids this morning asking about Mary. He and his buddy make a real pair.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Maybe it's time I checked out Mr. Gabriel.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I know where he parks his car.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Chinamen? Chosin? I've never heard her talk like that before.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Chosin Reservoir was a Korean war battle the Marines had against the Chinese, supposedly the bloodiest hand-to-hand fighting of the century. Someone been teaching that to your class?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Sure, right next to Jack 'N Jill.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Where would she have heard it?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Nobody I can think of.  Maybe one.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: You couldn't and tell a story like that to one.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: If I was smart I'd call the Sheriff or somebody in town who knows this place. Then again, there is one thing worse than getting killed.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Looking like an idiot if it's nothing.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: No, if someone has to fall a hundred feet down a black pit, he should at least be on official duty.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Then again, it is kind of spooky in there. Here, you can hold the flashlight.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe a bum or something.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: ...No. The voices. They were screaming and fighting over... theology. They don't sweat much about that in hell. But they do in... heaven.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: The son of a bitch. He carries it around with him like a photo album. A big, greasy cloud wherever he goes. They all do.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: How can that be heaven? Jesus Christ. How? I don't even believe in heaven.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: You dumb fucking assholes! How could you have done that!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: That extra chapter by St. John was right. It's a war... Just like the first one. Just like when the angel Michael beat Lucifer and cast him out. Only now they've turned on each other... Turned on each other in a civil war over theology.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Oh sweet God, theology.  God's morons!

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: How do you know know so much about that?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I just know.  Yes folks, the good news is that there's life after death in heaven. The bad news is that it's as screwed up as here.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: They are us. Aborted children. And they need us. They need our corrupt, dark souls for their fight. They need...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I don't know what this is. I don't know what I believe. I don't know if my sanity is lying back in that cave flopping around waiting for me. But I know one thing. Those... Those things aren't taking her!

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: In those... visions... did you ever see... God?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You know. Son of a bitch, the priest wanna-be actually figured it out. That's a rare club, son. At least down here.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Back away from the kid, man. Now.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: She won't feel anything, honest. I'll have to tear her apart of course -- just the way it goes -- but it'll be all right in the end. A good catholic boy like you, Mr. Daggett, you should be on my side.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You're gonna have to watch that profanity.

Speaker: jerry
Dialogue: Thanks man, I appreciate it. You're a sport.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You little pest, do you have any idea how hard it is to get one of those?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: You son of a bitch, why? Why do this?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Because I'm an angel, you miserable wretch! I kill first borns while their mothers watch! I turn whole cities into salt! I even, when I feel like it, rip the souls from little girls! And from now until eternity, the only thing you'll be able to count on in your pathetic little existence is never knowing why!  C'mon petunia, let's get on with it...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: She was coming up the street.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: They're not like you and me. You've got to cut their hearts out. The only thing God gave them.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: That's a start. How about the rest of it?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: That man over there. He's wanted. Murder. I'm taking him in.  -- Shit...

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: I think you're going to the hospital first.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Cuff him. We'll take him to the hospital in our car.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: -- No, you don't understand. You have to let me have him --

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Take off his sunglasses... Jesus Christ, just take off his sunglasses...

Speaker: fireman
Dialogue: He'll be all right. Just a bad hit.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: We have to get out of here.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: If you want Mary to stay alive past sundown we have to leave, and we have to do it now.

Speaker: telephone voice
Dialogue: County Coroner's office, Assistant Coroner Raphael speaking.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I mean, do you have any kind of plan here? Cause I'm just about of ideas, friend.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Do you even listen? Do you still come to places like this? Old Man, you have been calling me most of my goddamn life, but every time I get close, you just keep moving that far away. What's it to be? You want me to kill your henchmen? Can't you even control your own killers anymore?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: What do you want from me!

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: I am Bartholomew Grey Horse, born to the Deer Spring Clan, born for the Slow Talking People. Today I am the yataalii for Mary Tsosie of the Bitter Sky Clan.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Separate water source. Stocked grain. Only one possible approach. A man could, with the proper defenses, hold off an entire battalion for weeks. Months.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Which one of you is that talking, Mary? Or do you even know anymore?

Speaker: grey horse
Dialogue: We will start the Sing soon to remove the Yei spirit and stop the ghost sickness.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: This might not be the work of a Navaho ghost.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Now we sleep, Katherine. Tomorrow, after dark, we begin again.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Oh Lord, I can't do this. I can't do this anymore...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I can't. I can't do this tonight. Go away.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I can kill you, Katherine. I can lay you out and fill your mouth with your mother's feces. Or I can talk with you.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I am here, before you, in a form to put you at ease.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I rarely do this in person. I am, perhaps, somewhat out of touch.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: Oh, I am an angel. A very special one. The first. The oldest. The naive eagle scout, he once loved me above all others, and I him. It was the only true love for either of us, but like all true love, it couldn't possibly last.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: The winged party boys will come, Katherine. They'll come to feed on the guts of your little Mary.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: The naive eagle scout, he has his interests too. He even has a place for them, as I do for mine. Big, shiny place. You'd like it. Only it's been empty for a long time. Can't open till after the resurrection. The problem's with the hired help. Always had problems with the hired help. They're arrogant, boastful little pricks. Not like me. What I did I did for love. But they, the winged party boys, even before the park could open for its first customer, they started fighting over the popcorn stand.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: You see, Katherine, heaven can't start accepting guests till this fight is settled. And without people, there is no heaven. All those good and true souls left mouldering in the ground clutching their H-tickets and waiting and waiting and waiting... Some, lying down there with the worms century after century, they start to get doubts about the whole program. That's when, out of sheer boredom, some of them come to me. Because I'm always open for business. 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Even on Christmas.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: Some of the angels cheat. They sneak a few souls in to help with the fight. The really dark ones. And now one of them has found a special soul so wonderfully sick that it might just win it for them. And if one side wins, even the wrong one, then there's no fight. And if there's no fight, there can be a heaven.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I'd be very unhappy.  I am here to help you and the little bitch not because I love you, not because I care about you, but because I want this war to go on and on and on.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: I bring you the chance to save your Mary, Katherine. And along the way, stop the resurrection.

Speaker: figure
Dialogue: Listen when I speak. Now go to bed, Katherine. Tomorrow, I promise you, is a big day.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: For now. They start again tomorrow.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: And at the end of it?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: The Enemy Way chant removes the invading yei ghost.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Will it work on a general's soul?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Then I must be doing it wrong.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: The main one. Satan. Lucifer. The dark angel. You know.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: What did he have to say?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: That he did it all for love. That and I have a choice. Mary's life or a billion souls waiting in the pipeline for heavenland to open.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: We can double date next time if it's that important to you.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: You don't understand, I've spent my whole life...  I don't suppose it would occur to anyone in authority to fill me in on what's going on every once in awhile, huh? Shit!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Did he say anything about the Nicene Council? About the rank of Jesus Christ in the holy Trinity?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: It didn't seem important to him.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: This may be your last chance to tell it.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: The other night, you were talking about waiting for a voice to call you to something. Well, let me tell you, the worst thing that can happen to you is to be called to something. Since I can remember a voice from somewhere deep in the Church called me. So loud and so often that by thirteen I knew I was going to be a priest. You know what that's like? My parents, friends, all of them thought I was crazy. But see, I had this voice. The voice that kept coaxing me along, telling me there was a reason. So I entered the seminary and was half way to my starched white collar when my mother, father, and my little brother were wiped out in a car crash.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I had never asked anything of the voice. Not when the neighborhood kids made fun of me, not when my father looked down at me like some knock-kneed faggot. I never questioned a damn thing. But on the morning I spent looking down at three parallel graves, I asked it one question. Why. Why were these people taken from me? And the voice, that same voice that would wrench me out of my sleep some nights with its jabbering, it was suddenly stone silent. It was the only question I ever asked of it and it just left me hanging in the fucking wind...

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: So after that I traded in priest school for homicide school. Because if God wouldn't talk to me the devil sure as hell would, and his ways were a lot easier to understand.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: We've never seen God, have we? Not in any of this.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Yeah, He's certainly a shy son of a bitch, I'll give Him that.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Maybe we're not supposed to. Maybe that's faith.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Do you still have faith in anything, Katherine?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I have faith in Mary. And that I'm going to save that little girl from those creeping things out there. From all of them.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Maybe you were called to something after all.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Don't -- Don't hurt me, man. My wallet's in the dresser.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Don't be such a materialist, John.  No end to your bad habits.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: You ought to have that nose looked at, man.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Where are they, John? Katherine and Mary? Where would they go?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: No, really. I don't know. The school maybe.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Now you're not even trying, John. You're Katherine's best friend. She tells you everything.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I can help you remember, John...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Someone's going to die here soon. I'll just be a minute.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: There's no visitors allowed in ICU.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: The timing's important. I can smell these things, you know.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Whoa, not just yet. Come on back. That's it...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: What are we going to do if he comes?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: There's no phone here? Radio?  If we were smart we'd leave. Get to a town. A sheriff station.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Mary's ceremony isn't over yet. The Enemy Ghost Way. The alien spirit hasn't been driven out.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Do you really believe in the ceremony?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Would you have believed in any of this three days ago?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: So we stay and dump the General's soul.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: With one shot left. The spares --  We're going to have to come up with something.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: I always forget how cold it gets in the desert.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Mr. Daggett, I presume. How's the faith?

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Come come, must you be so wishy-washy about everything? With the absent- minded eagle scout, I can see that. But you're looking at the devil man, say something.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Much better. Can I have some coffee?

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: I have come to remind you that the winged party boys are just that: spoiled boys. You are armed, however pathetically, with the one thing they never really understood: theology. It's not much, but that's life.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Is this supposed to be our "win one for The Ripper" speech?

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Don't press your luck, Mr. Daggett.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Have you ever considered Katherine, that the great absentee landlord, the soft-eyed eagle scout your childhood prayers are for, is just using you? That you're only the exterminator to get rid of his pests?

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: God's junkies are coming, Katherine. And when they do, all hell is going to break loose...

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Say, Ma'am, any idea where I can find Old Woman Butte?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I don't suppose you could be just a tad more specific. Madge.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Not for a while, I'm afraid. Funniest thing.

Speaker: madge
Dialogue: Take 522 to the Sonsela Wash cut- off. First dirt road go left. Twenty, twenty-five miles you'll see it. Big, black and all alone.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: You could always lend a hand.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Is there any way to speed this up?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Stay inside. It's only one round, so make it count.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: You ought to come work for us. Upstairs. We sneak the odd civilian in now and then, you know. You'd like it. Nobody tells you when to go to bed, can eat all the ice cream you want. And you get to kill. All day and all night. Just like an angel.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Save yourself, friend. Why go to the wall with the bitch and her rug rat? It'll all turn out the same anyway. Here or in heaven, we're still gonna tear the kid apart.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I'm not an angel, heaven or hell. I'm a man you eyeless puke, which means I have one thing you never will. A soul. And though I may, somewhere inside, believe in a God, I will never, never, believe in you.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: A little speechy today, aren't we?  Okay pal, have it your way.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: This is going to really, really hurt.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: C'mon, son, out with it. Make this one count.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Running around acting like this is really about whether Christ is just the son of God or if he is God. Bullshit! That's not what this is about at all, is it?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Then prove it to me, Gabriel. I studied three fucking years of theology before I picked up a gun. C'mon, you're chief goddamn angel, I'm just a little man. Prove to me Christ is just a son and less than God. Prove it!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Because you can't! Because this war isn't about some obscure medieval hangup. You're just jealous.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Try me, Gabriel. Go on. Prove to me the temporal nature of the Trinity. Show me through logic how the Son of the Word can be separated from the Father. Fight me with philosophy, Gabriel!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Because you and your army are wrong! And you know it. You knew it sixteen centuries ago.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: We don't have to listen to him! He's just a son!

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: That's it. You're jealous. Jealous He could love something more than you...

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: If you wanted to know so badly, Gabriel, why didn't you just ask Him? Why didn't you just ask God?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Because He doesn't talk to us anymore!

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Relax folks, it's just a soul.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: I'm getting real tired of you.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Heaven, darling. Heaven. At least get the zip code right.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: It's all the same, isn't it?

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: No. In heaven we believe in love.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: And what do you love, Gabriel?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: That's all it is for you anymore, Gabriel, isn't it? Just the killing and the burning. You don't work for God anymore. You don't fight for love.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Oh man, this just isn't my day.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: But I remember the last one. Michael's war.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: But lots of angels were with me. every one followed their leader out of heaven.

Speaker: gabriel
Dialogue: Yeah yeah, I was there, remember?

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Except one. Oh, he was with me all right. He hated the Eagle Scout. Envied the power He gave to His Son. But this angel never came out front during the war. And when it ended he thought maybe, maybe the Eagle Scout didn't notice. So he laid low and towed the company line till he could start his own war. It was all just jealousy.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: But maybe He did notice. Maybe that's why I'm here.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: You've always been a part of me, Gabriel. And now it's time to come home.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: More will come... To look for the soul...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: And they won't find it. Not in Mary.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: It's going to be okay... We're all going to be okay...

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I can't quite bring myself to say thank you.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: Not necessarily. Maybe I like you. Maybe I want you to come with me.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: You owe me, Katherine. And you're going to ask me to take you home.

Speaker: lucifer
Dialogue: You will. You will because any other way is going to be more awful than you can imagine.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Then you've picked the wrong person this time. I've just about had it up to here with ghosts. So you can put away the horror movie sneer and the K-Mart halloween eyes, because we know you now. We know you all. And if you want to force the issue then go ahead because you're just another angel to me. Take a look at your buddy Gabriel. Then ask yourself, do you really, really want to fuck with us?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: I don't think so, honey... I don't think so...

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I thought I told you to give me a call if anything snarled.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Pretty violent guy, Gabriel. Even for out here.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Caught up with him at the village?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: What were you doing way up here?

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Enemy Ghost Way for Mary Tsosie.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Don't have any idea where the body is I suppose.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Well, if he's alive he won't get far out there. Us or the coyotes, it'll be the same.  I rang your office in LA. They don't have a warrant out for a Gabriel. Or anybody else in Arizona.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: I hadn't gotten around to it.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Sort of an out of pocket thing.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: That woman lying at the bottom of the arroyo, the one still in her hospital gown, know anything about that?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: This Gabriel was sure one busy dude.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You'll be going back to Los Angeles now?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Don't do much but breathe the next few days. And get to a hospital. You're going to need some serious stitches.

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Say hi to Hollywood for me.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Thank you. I feel worse.  They lean on you much?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Not really. I think they might have even understood. One of them's related to this clan. He'll give us a ride back if we want.

Speaker: daggett
Dialogue: Good. I think I've about run out of hospitality with the sheriff's department.

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: Do you think it's really over?

Speaker: katherine
Dialogue: When I die, I want you with me.
